items.factHi: Vaccines protect you and your family from serious diseases.
items.tipHi: Vaccines contain weakened or inactive parts of a disease that trigger your body's immune response. They are safe and prevent serious illnesses like polio, measles, and tetanus.

items.factHi: They should eat nutritious food for their health and baby's growth.
items.tipHi: Pregnant women need extra nutrients including iron, folic acid, and calcium. Eating balanced meals helps ensure a healthy pregnancy and baby development.

items.mythHi: Boiled water is bad for health.
items.factHi: Boiling kills germs and makes water safe to drink.
items.tipHi: Boil water for at least 10-15 minutes to remove harmful bacteria, viruses, and parasites. This simple method prevents waterborne diseases like diarrhea and cholera.

items.mythHi: Fever should not be treated with cold water.
items.factHi: Cold compress helps reduce fever safely.
items.tipHi: Use a clean cloth soaked in room temperature or slightly cool water on the forehead. This helps bring down body temperature naturally. Avoid ice-cold water as it may cause shivering.

items.mythHi: Only city hospitals provide good treatment.
items.factHi: Government Primary Health Centres (PHCs) also give free, quality care.
items.tipHi: PHCs provide free medicines, vaccinations, maternal care, and basic treatments. ASHA workers and ANMs are trained to help with common health issues. Visit your nearest PHC for checkups.

items.mythHi: Eating papaya during pregnancy causes miscarriage.
items.factHi: Ripe papaya is safe and full of vitamins.
items.tipHi: Fully ripe papaya is excellent for pregnant women as it contains Vitamin A and C. Avoid raw or semi-ripe papaya as it contains latex which might be harmful.

items.mythHi: Mental illness is caused by evil spirits.
items.factHi: It is a medical condition treatable by doctors.
items.tipHi: Mental health issues are brain disorders, not supernatural events. Psychiatrists and psychologists can treat them with therapy and medication.

items.factHi: Antibiotics only kill bacteria, not viruses.
items.tipHi: Colds and flu are caused by viruses. Taking antibiotics for them won't help and can increase antibiotic resistance. Rest and hydration are best.

items.mythHi: Men don't need to worry about family planning.
items.factHi: Family planning is a shared responsibility.
items.tipHi: Men play a crucial role. Condoms are a safe, effective method of contraception that involves men and also protects against sexually transmitted infections.

items.mythHi: Drinking less water reduces swelling during pregnancy.
items.factHi: Drinking enough water actually helps reduce swelling.
items.tipHi: Staying hydrated helps flush out waste and prevents fluid retention. Pregnant women should drink 8-10 glasses of water daily.

items.factHi: Glasses correct vision and reduce eye strain.
items.tipHi: Glasses help you see clearly and stop your eyes from working too hard. They do not weaken your eyes; refusing to wear them might cause headaches.

items.mythHi: Dengue mosquitoes only bite at night.
items.factHi: They primarily bite during the day.
items.tipHi: Aedes mosquitoes, which spread dengue, are most active early morning and late afternoon. Use repellents and wear full sleeves even during the day.

items.mythHi: Newborns should be given honey or water first.
items.factHi: Only breastmilk should be given for 6 months.
items.tipHi: Breastmilk contains all the water and nutrients a baby needs. Honey can be dangerous for infants under 1 year due to botulism risk.

items.mythHi: TB is hereditary and cannot be cured.
items.factHi: TB is infectious but completely curable.
items.tipHi: Tuberculosis spreads through air when someone coughs. It is not genetic. With a full course of DOTS treatment, it can be cured completely.

items.mythHi: Snake bites should be cut and sucked.
items.factHi: Never cut or suck the wound; go to hospital.
items.tipHi: Immobilize the bitten limb and keep the patient calm. Cutting or sucking wastes time and can cause infection. Antivenom at a hospital is the only cure.
